hints.content:
Coordinates are listed as $(\blueD{x},\greenD{y})$.

So, for $( \blueD{4}, \greenD{8})$ our $x$-coordinate is $\blueD4$, and our $y$-coordinate is $\greenD8$.

Let's start by going to $\blueD{4}$ on the $x$-axis:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e2b711288e31f543d6086e41da670153829d90da)

Now we go up to $\greenD8$ on the $y$-axis, and plot the point $(\blueD{4}, \greenD{8})$:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b20631f4e398c31d5fd6d79dbae273a8db1a99dc)

The answer

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/26caef76d9c7165c88a4c945d5466c158e12daac)

Coordinates are listed as $(\blueD{x},\greenD{y})$.

So, for $( \blueD{3}, \greenD{4})$ our $x$-coordinate is $\blueD3$, and our $y$-coordinate is $\greenD4$.

Let's start by going to $\blueD{3}$ on the $x$-axis:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f8469fc47855daae47a367091b0fb55218e9f0e7)

Now we go up to $\greenD4$ on the $y$-axis, and plot the point $(\blueD{3}, \greenD{4})$:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c8ae76c4b7cdd44d17f44a32cb04bdc07d53d6ad)

The answer

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/dbe483d4e69bc4160e190353be24d1a5885a5ce2)

The living room's ordered pair is $(\maroonB{18},\redD{18})$.  This means that the living room has $\maroonB{18}$ pink balloons and $\redD{18}$ red balloons.  Let's graph that on the coordinate plane.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/bf901c360e7f3b8f7a08e3cd306195f5b15ee017)

This coordinate plane correctly shows the numbers of balloons in each room.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1e1e7c6564a07e249b8fb6e0c5c9db3d3c12f8c1)

question.content:
For Valentines Day, Aubrey blows up pink and red balloons for each room.  The ordered pairs show how many pink balloons and how many red balloons, respectively, are in each room.

Living room: $(18,18)$  
Dining room: $(15,10)$  
Kitchen: $(9,8)$

**Which coordinate plane correctly shows the numbers of balloons in each room?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Let's see what point $A$ lines up with on each axis.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8a3056a70038fc40f0bb48a3c9011dd6d8a9dcd8)
Point $A$ tells us that a can with an $11\,\text{cm}$ diameter has an $18\,\text{cm}$ height.

question.content:
Grocer Edwards graphs the relationship between the diameter and heights of different cans in his store.  The graph is below.

**What is the meaning of point $A$?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b422c9a3a31b87a5f0c1785848e3b0a634121c26)

choices.content: A can with an $18\,\text{cm}$ diameter has an $11\,\text{cm}$ height.
A can with an $11\,\text{cm}$ diameter has an $18\,\text{cm}$ height.
A can with an $10\,\text{cm}$ diameter has an $18\,\text{cm}$ height.
A can with an $18\,\text{cm}$ diameter has an $10\,\text{cm}$ height.

hints.content:
To graph $(\blue{0}, \pink{8\dfrac12})$,  we move $\blue{\text{right 0}}$ from the origin $(0,0)$, then $\pink{\text{up }\pink{8\dfrac12}}$ from there. 


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1ab17b9c8b7ab7b89bafb604329f656a147e3cf2)

To graph $(\blue{-4}, \pink{-9})$,  we move $\blue{\text{left 4}}$ from the origin $(0,0)$, then $\pink{\text{down 9}}$ from there. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a8a06da906cc953728e292ca2515888787781d25)

To graph $(\blue{-6}, \pink{5})$,  we move $\blue{\text{left 6}}$ from the origin $(0,0)$, then $\pink{\text{up 5}}$ from there. 


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1d311399447cab03a390109d02e2e8b2fa06330e)

$(0, 8\dfrac12)$, $(-4,-9)$, and $(-6,5)$ are graphed below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1716f75cf9235d23e3322a49787ca0cac46744e2)

question.content:
**Drag the dots to plot $(0, 8\dfrac12)$, $(-4,-9)$, and $(-6,5)$.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
To get to point $\green{A}$ from the origin $(0,0)$, we move left to $\green{-2}$ and up to $\green{4}$.


To get to point $\purple{B}$ from the origin  $(0,0)$, we move right $\purple{0}$ and down to $\purple{-3}$.


To get to point $\blue{C}$ from the origin  $(0,0)$, we move right to $\blue{4}$ and down to $\blue{-4}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c618913a4cb548c7bbae6c5ef4491047d34d180f)

Point | Ordered pair
- | - 
$\green{A}$ | $\green{(-2,4)}$
$\purple{B}$| $\purple{(0,-3)}$
$\blue{C}$| $\blue{(4,-4)}$

question.content:

Point | Ordered pair
- | -

hints.content:
Let's plot the two points representing the hot dogs and the mustard: $(6,4)$ and $(6,-3)$.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7d638802d47ccac1ac54c1180aca7625bcc1d56e)
The hot dogs and mustard are $7$ units apart.

question.content:
A coordinate map of the local grocery store is shown below.  Hot dogs are located at the point $(6,4)$. Mustard is located at  the point $(6,-3)$.

**Plot the hot dogs and mustard on the map.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

**How far are the hot dogs from the mustard?**  
[[☃ input-number 1]] units

hints.content:
$\purple{\text{Science}}$ is $6$ units from $\pink{\text{art}}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6ca58071b3b52ee69fde23b497c10ce9b4b1cbe2)

So, $\green{\text{Spanish club}}$ will be $\dfrac{6}{2} = 3$ units away from both $\purple{\text{science}}$ and $\pink{\text{art}}$.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ef3560ea1a5885ac99bc16f79443f930ec6aadd7)
Callie should graph Spanish club at coordinates $(-2,-5)$.

question.content:
Callie graphed the locations of several places in her school on the coordinate plane shown below.  Spanish club meets halfway between the science room and art room.

**At what coordinates should Callie graph Spanish club?**  
 $($[[☃ input-number 1]]$,\,$[[☃ input-number 2]]$)$



![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ec812913165628a1663b6397ec2d813c5d8a7b93)

choices.content: In a city with an elevation of $6 \text{ km}$ *below* sea level, the temperature was $5 ^{\circ}\text{C}$ *below* zero.
In a city with an elevation of $6 \text{ km}$ *above* sea level, the temperature was $5 ^{\circ}\text{C}$ *below* zero.
In a city with an elevation of $6 \text{ km}$ *below* sea level, the temperature was $5 ^{\circ}\text{C}$ *above* zero.
In a city with an elevation of $6 \text{ km}$ *above* sea level, the temperature was $5 ^{\circ}\text{C}$ *above* zero.

hints.content:
Let's plot each point on the coordinate plane.


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/614bdd6be63d64154b826188352c2b0d9ee209ff)

Now, let's label the axes and quadrants: 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0cd2c2a5de92c7a6aeef7ab51edc6ddfe138c73c)

Ordered pair | Location
:-: | - 
$\blue{(-2\dfrac12,-7)}$ | Quadrant III
$\green{(0,6)}$ | $y$-axis
$\pink{(-5,0)}$ | $x$-axis

question.content:
**Select the quadrant or axis where each ordered pair is located on a coordinate plane.**

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

hints.content:
$a$ is the $x$-coordinate.  

If a point's $x$-coordinate is $0$, then the point must be located on the $y$-axis.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/68124d507b28793600b9ded6fdfd86878e369c07)

Point $P$ is located on the $y$-axis.

question.content:
The ordered pair $(a, b)$ gives the location of point $P$ on the coordinate plane. The value of $a$ is $0$, but $b$ is not zero.  

**Where could point $P$ be located on the coordinate plane?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: When we reflect a point across an axis, the $\blue{\text{distance between the point and the axis}}$ stays the same, but is $\pink{\text{flipped to the opposite side}}$.

In this case, point $B$ is a reflection of point $A$ across the $y$-axis.


![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f28a87bec734b13aa5026c125213ff654b6d6db2)

question.content:
**The point $B$ is a reflection of point $A$ across which axis?**

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/93fbaa8bfb1b42a6698b1f1e6e7b4b6193a927fc)

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: Since we are reflecting across the $y$-axis, the $\blue{\text{distance point $A$ is from the $y$-axis}}$ will stay the same, but will be  $\pink{\text{flipped to the opposite side}}$.

$\blue{A}$ is $4$ units *right* of the $y$-axis, so its reflection is $4$ units *left* of the $y$-axis. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ff1e1fceb3b0c4fa7c8050c80364e33b716988f8)


The reflected point is $(-4, -6)$.

*Fun fact: when we reflect across the $y$-axis, the sign on the $x$-coordinate changes.*

The correct graph is shown below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6ae9a5fcf60737104a49d641ef0364c8a7cf1fcc)

question.content:
**Drag the dot to plot  the reflection of $A$  across the $y$-axis.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content: We know that $c=0$ because $(c, 4)$ has the same horizontal coordinate as $(0,0)$.
We know that $b=4$ because $(6, b)$ has the same vertical coordinate as $(c,4)$.
We know that $a=6$ because $(a, 0)$ has the same horizontal coordinate as $(6,b)$.

Now that we know that $c = 0$, $b = 4$, and $a = 6$, we can sort the expressions from least to greatest:


 |  | |
- | - | -
$c$ | $b$ | $a$

question.content:
**Sort the following expressions from least to greatest based on the coordinates of the rectangle below.**

[[☃ sorter 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4a95c295f3fea45e266f938fdaf69b415afd357e)

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/01a12423748bccec2b2bfc3519f6418285c2af96.png)

Since $A(\red{5},\blue{ 1})$ and $B(\red{7}, \blue{1})$ have the same $y$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $x$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\red{7}-\red{5}&=2.\end{align}$
The length of side $AB$ is $2$ units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(5, 1),$ $B(7,1)$, $C(7, 6)$, and $D(5, 6)$.  

**Given these coordinates, what is the length of side $AB$ of this rectangle?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] units

hints.content:
Remember that an ordered pair is in the form $(x, y)$.  

Starting at the origin, or $(0, 0)$, the $x$-coordinate tells us how many units to count left or right, and the $y$-coordinate tells us how many units to count up or down.

When we plot all $6$ points, we end up with a hexagon that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/bf61da33d252cc8160a6def452c08158f538adaf.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to create  a hexagon with vertices at the following points.**  

$(−8,9), (−9,7), (−9,4), (−6,1), (−3,5), (−4,9)$  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Remember that an ordered pair is in the form $(x, y)$.  

Starting at the origin, or $(0, 0)$, the $x$-coordinate tells us how many units to count left or right, and the $y$-coordinate tells us how many units to count up or down.

When we plot all $5$ points and connect them so there are no overlapping segments, we end up with a pentagon that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/59dfe4f9e4e5bd2538d908f25b6989ff90453ce3.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to create a pentagon with vertices at the following points.**  

$(−7.5, 0), (0,6.5), (6.5,0), (0, -4.5), (−5.5, -3.5)$  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know three of the trapezoid's four vertices are at $(-6,6)$, $(-6,-2)$, and $(2,-2)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/906e81c29e2a304d1ce5e18e2af19c6d3c84a2d8.png)

We know there is a right angle at $(-6,6)$ and that the trapezoid has a side $10$ units long that is parallel to the $x$-axis, so we should draw a segment extending $10$ units to the right  from $(-6,6)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3e247248b82cccf4c9776d7145514a0423f11d13.png)

We end up with a trapezoid that looks like this:  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/941c9f30114d0fb1010a62640113bd9bf653a7a3.png)

question.content:
**Click on the graph to draw a trapezoid with right angles at $(-6,6)$ and $(-6,-2)$, another vertex at $(2,-2)$, and a side $10$ units long that is parallel to the $x$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
We know that two of the triangle's three vertices are at  $(0,5)$ and $(-8,0)$, so let's start by plotting and connecting those points. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5b6482a2587fd31af0018965aa5a84c1267374ed)

We know the side along the $y$-axis is $10$ units long. If we draw the third side vertically upward from $(5,0)$, we won't get an isosceles triangle.  So let's draw the segment extending $10$ units down from $(5,0)$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1a1c1a89dc8e703ddf2cf399e76f8f6446822c9f)

We end up with  a triangle that looks like this:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/526efd990b440846a87bee55afbf0afb300028df)

question.content:
**Click on the graph below to draw an isosceles triangle with vertices at $(0,5)$ and $(-8,0)$, and a side measuring $10$ units on the $y$-axis.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]
